flashcards.front: Bengal Gazette / Original Calcutta General Advertiser (1780)?
flashcards.back: Founder: James Augustus Hickey. Place: Calcutta. Spread: Bengal, Bihar, Orissa. First newspaper published in India in English. Known for independent journalism and outspoken criticism of British East India Company
Founder: Richard Johnston. Place: Madras. First newspaper to be published from Madras
Place: Bombay. First newspaper to be published from Bombay. In English, came with title Indian Herald
Founder: Harish Chandra Ray. Place: Calcutta. First Bengali newspaper
Founder: Raja Ram Mohan Roy. Place: Calcutta. Spread: Bengal and Bihar. Bengali weekly newspaper that promoted social and religious reform
Founder: Raja Ram Mohan Roy. Place: Calcutta. Spread: Bengal and Bihar. First Persian language journal that discussed current events and social issues
Place: Calcutta. First Urdu language paper. Was run by an English Firm
Founder: Raja Ram Mohan Roy and Dwarkanath Tagore. Place: Calcutta. Weekly published in 4 different languages: English, Bengali, Persian and Hindi
Founder: Fardunjee Marzban. Place: Bombay. First newspaper in Gujarati
Founder: Bankim Chandra Chatterji. Place: Calcutta. In Bengali Language
Founder: Thomas Bennett. Place: Bombay. Later from 1861 came to be known as Times of India, published till date. Founded by Robert Knight but actual publication started by Thomas Bennett
Founder: Girishchandra Ghosh. Place: Calcutta. Later Harishchandra Mukherji became owner-cum-editor

Founder: Dadabhai Naoroji. Place: Bombay. Spread: Bombay, Gujarat, Sindh. Gujarati fortnightly newspaper advocated for Indian economic and political rights. Naoroji used it to educate Indians about their rights and mobilise them against British rule
Founder: Dadabhai Naoroji. Place: Bombay. Later incorporated into the Indian Spectator

Founder: Dwarkanath VidyaBhushan. Place: Calcutta. Spread: Bengal and Bihar. Bengali weekly newspaper promoted social, political and educational reforms. Used to advocate for women's rights, education, and widow remarriage
Founder: Devendra Nath Tagore and Man Mohan Ghosh. Place: Calcutta. Spread: Bengal and Bihar. English fortnightly newspaper
Started by Girish Chandra Ghosh and later taken over by Surendranath Banerjee. Place: Calcutta. Spread: Bengal and Bihar
Founder: George Allen. Place: Allahabad. Spread: United Provinces
Founder: Sisir Kumar ghosh and Motilal Ghosh. Place: Calcutta. Spread: Bengal and Bihar. Bengali in beginning, later became English. Leading voice for bengali middle class
Founder: Sir Syed Ahmed Khan. Place: Aligarh. Spread: North India. Urdu language journal advocating for women's education, reform in Muslim family law, modernization of Muslim society
Founder: Robert Knight. Place: Calcutta. Later renamed as The Statesman
Founder: G.S. Iyer, Vir Raghavacharya and Subba Rao Pandit. Place: Madras. Spread: Madras and Mysore. Initially weekly newspaper, known for moderate political view
Founder: G. Subramaniya Iyer. Place: Madras. One of the earliest Tamil newspapers and the longest in print
Founder: G.P. Verma. Place: Lucknow. Spread: United Provinces
Founder: Bal Gangadhar Tilak. Place: Poona. Spread: Bombay and Central India. Marathi language newspaper advocated for Indian self-rule. Mahratta (1881): An English weekly
Founder: Dayal Singh Majeetha. Place: Lahore. Spread: Punjab and North India. Daily newspaper
Founder: Pandit Dayanand Saraswati. Place: Lahore. Spread: Punjab and North India. Published in both English and Hindi
Founder: Maulavi Zakaullah. Place: Lahore. Spread: Punjab and North India
Founder: Behramji Malabari. Place: Bombay. Spread: Bombay and Gujarat
Founder: Gopal Krishna Agarkar. Place: Poona. Spread: Bombay and Central India. Marathi language newspaper promoted social reform
Founder: GK Gokhale. Place: Nagpur. Spread: central India. Published in both English and Marathi. Advocated for social reform and economic development
Founder: Gopalhari Deshmukh. Place: Poona. Spread: Bombay and Central India
Founder: Madan Mohan Malviya. Place: Allahabad. Spread: United Provinces

Founder: P. Aiyasami, B. R. Rajam Iyer, G. G. Narasimhacharya, B. V. Kamesvara Iyer at behest of Swami Vivekananda. Place: Calcutta. Spread: India and the world. English language monthly journal promoted Hindu philosophy and culture
Founder: Swami Vivekananda. Place: Calcutta. Spread: India and the world
Founder: M.K Gandhi. Place: Durban, South Africa. Spread: South Africa and India. Weekly newspaper advocated for rights of Indian immigrants
Founder: M.K Gandhi. Place: Ahmedabad. Spread: Bombay Presidency. Weekly journal promoted Gandhi's philosophy of non-violence and civil disobedience
Founder: M.K Gandhi. Place: Ahmedabad. Spread: Bombay. Gujarati language weekly promoted social reforms and Gandhi's philosophy
Founder: M.K Gandhi. Place: Ahmedabad. Spread: Bombay. English and Hindi weekly journal advocated for rights of Dalits
Founder: Brahmabandhab Upadhyay. Place: Bengal
Founder: Barindra Kumar Ghosh and Bhupendra Dutta. Place: Bengal. Political weekly served as propaganda organ for revolutionary organisation Anushilan Samiti
Founder: Aurobindo Ghosh. Place: Puducherry. Spread: India and the world. Published in English
Founder: E.V. Ramaswamy Naicker (Periyar). In Tamil language
Founder: Maulana Mohammad Ali. Place: Calcutta. Spread: Bengal and Bihar. English language weekly advocated for Indian self-rule and Muslim rights
Founder: Abul Kalam Azad. Place: Calcutta. Spread: Bengal and Bihar. Urdu weekly supported Indian self-rule and Muslim rights
Founder: Abul Kalam Azad. Place: Calcutta. Spread: Bengal and Bihar. Published in Urdu
Founder: Abul Kalam Azad. Place: Calcutta. Spread: Bengal and Bihar. Urdu weekly newspaper promoted Islamic thoughts and culture
Started by Firoze Shah Mehta and edited by B. G. Horniman. Place: Bombay. Spread: Bombay and Gujarat. Daily newspaper
Founder: Annie Besant. Place: Madras. Spread: Madras and Mysore
Founder: Motilal Nehru. Place: Allahabad. Spread: United Provinces
Founder: Sunder Singh Lyallpuri Later edited by K M Panikkar. Place: Delhi. Spread: All India. English language daily newspaper, used as part of the Akali Dal Movement
Founder: B.R Ambedkar. Place: Bombay. Spread: Bombay. Marathi language weekly advocated for rights of Dalits
Founder: B.R. Ambedkar. Marathi fortnightly
Founder: C. Rajagopalachari. Place: Madras. Spread: Madras and Mysore. Published in English
Founder: Tarak Nath Das. Place: Canada and USA. Spread in India and the world. English language journal advocated for self-rule and international cooperation
Founder: Madan Mohan Malaviya. Place: Lucknow. Spread: United Provinces. Hindi language daily newspaper advocated for Hindu nationalism
Founder: Sachindranath Sanyal. Place: Bengal
Founder: Jawaharlal Nehru. Place: Established in Lucknow. Details: Founded as a tool to win independence. Banned by British government in 1942 during Quit India movement till 1945
Founder: Shyamji Krishnavarma. Place of Publication: London
Founder: Madam Bikaji Cama. Place of Publication: Paris
Founder: Virendranath Chattopadhyaya. Place of Publication: Berlin

Founder: Lala Hardayal. Place of Publication: San Francisco. Details: The Ghadar Party put out this weekly, meaning revolt, using a small hand press. It first came out in Urdu, then Gurumukhi. Later it was also published in Gujarati, Hindi, English, German etc

mcq.question: First newspaper published in India in English (1780)?
mcq.explanation: Bengal Gazette/Original Calcutta General Advertiser (1780) by James Augustus Hickey was first newspaper in India in English.

mcq.question: First Bengali newspaper (1818)?
mcq.explanation: Bengal Gazette (1818) by Harish Chandra Ray was first Bengali newspaper.

mcq.question: Raja Ram Mohan Roy founded which newspapers?
mcq.explanation: Raja Ram Mohan Roy founded Sambad Kaumudi (1821 Bengali), Mirat-ul-Akbar (1822 Persian), and Banga-Duta (1822 with Dwarkanath Tagore, 4 languages).

mcq.question: First Urdu language paper (1822)?
mcq.explanation: Jam-i-Jahan Numah (1822) was first Urdu language paper, run by an English Firm.

mcq.question: First Gujarati newspaper (1822)?
mcq.explanation: Bombay Samachar (1822) by Fardunjee Marzban was first newspaper in Gujarati.

mcq.question: Bombay Times (1838) later became?
mcq.explanation: Bombay Times (1838) by Thomas Bennett later from 1861 came to be known as Times of India, published till date.

mcq.question: Dadabhai Naoroji founded which newspapers?
options: Rast Goftar (1851) and Voice of India (1883)
mcq.explanation: Dadabhai Naoroji founded Rast Goftar (1851, Gujarati) and Voice of India (1883, later incorporated into Indian Spectator).

mcq.question: Kesari (1881) and Mahratta (1881) founded by?
mcq.explanation: Kesari (Marathi) and Mahratta (English weekly) both founded in 1881 by Bal Gangadhar Tilak, advocated for Indian self-rule.

mcq.question: M.K. Gandhi founded how many newspapers?
options: Four (Indian Opinion 1903, Young India 1919, Nav Jeevan 1929, Harijan 1932)
mcq.explanation: Gandhi founded Indian Opinion (1903 Durban), Young India (1919 Ahmedabad), Nav Jeevan (1929 Gujarati), Harijan (1932 for Dalits).

mcq.question: Abul Kalam Azad founded which newspapers?
mcq.explanation: Abul Kalam Azad founded Al-Balagh (1912), The Azad (1912), and Al-Hilal (1912), all Urdu newspapers supporting Indian self-rule and Muslim rights.

mcq.question: B.R. Ambedkar founded which newspapers for Dalits?
mcq.explanation: B.R. Ambedkar founded Mook Nayak (1920, Marathi weekly) and Bahishkrit Bharat (1927, Marathi fortnightly) advocating for rights of Dalits.

mcq.question: Yugantar (1906) served as propaganda organ for?
mcq.explanation: Yugantar (1906) by Barindra Kumar Ghosh and Bhupendra Dutta served as propaganda organ for revolutionary organisation Anushilan Samiti.

mcq.question: National Herald (1938) founded by?
mcq.explanation: National Herald (1938) founded by Jawaharlal Nehru in Lucknow as tool to win independence, banned 1942 during Quit India.

mcq.question: Indian Sociologist published from?
mcq.explanation: Indian Sociologist by Shyamji Krishnavarma published from London.

mcq.question: Bande Mataram founded by Madam Bikaji Cama published from?
mcq.explanation: Bande Mataram founded by Madam Bikaji Cama published from Paris.

mcq.question: Talvar founded by Virendranath Chattopadhyaya published from?
mcq.explanation: Talvar founded by Virendranath Chattopadhyaya published from Berlin.

mcq.question: Ghadar (meaning revolt) founded by?
mcq.explanation: Ghadar founded by Lala Hardayal, published from San Francisco by Ghadar Party.

mcq.question: Ghadar initially came out in which languages?
options: Urdu, then Gurumukhi, later Gujarati, Hindi, English, German etc
mcq.explanation: Ghadar first came out in Urdu, then Gurumukhi, later also published in Gujarati, Hindi, English, German etc.
